Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
@Deleted User 

> @Bryan_Beus problem is not the language, we could be using python, go, or elm, the problem would still remain, because the root cause is the usage of the package manager without proper supervision.

Right, I understand. JS is the language i know best (which isn't saying much).

The language is fairly easy to use. I don't get why people complain about it, unless they're talking pre-ES6.

Compared to C++, JS is a cinch.

But the way we've built the JS environment is the issue, like you said. 

I'd be interested to look into WebAssembly. I know the basic talking points about it, but am not far enough into C++ yet to actually use it. 

I wonder if the upcoming C++ package manager will make C++ as big of a secure risk...

Content: If you simply write x=5 then it‚Äôs equivalent to window.x=5 which is global

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: Of course, browsers would have to have security checks against that.

Content: If you use a linter it will throw an error

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: I think I played around with this like a year ago or something.

Author: Andy#1801
Content: The reason this us allowed is because all global functions belong to the window object

new Promise()

new window.Promise()

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so what happens if an upstream module is updated with a critical security update to path a vulnerability?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you update right away, a real exploit can sneak in

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: if you dont, you are exposed to the announced vulnerability

Author: Andy#1801
Content: You have to lock them to the exact version.

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so the "critical update" is just a minor update

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: is it possible to change the code without changing the version?

Author: Andy#1801
Content: You have to manually update every dependency

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: but modules are allowed to make requests over the internet

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: what stops it from getting code externally? at first it is benign

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: so version numbers dont matter

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: everyone is all gungho about all the automated build stuff...

Author: Andy#1801
Content: Well a hacker will certainly play by the rules when trying to exploit an app üòâ

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: with iguana, i wrote virtually everything from scratch

Author: Andy#1801
Content: You cannot assume that a patch version upgrade is just that. Unless it is enforced by the ecosystem (like it is in elm).

Author: Andy#1801
Content: The important question is if the dev can change the code that is on npm after it has already been released

Author: Andy#1801
Content: Because then even locking to a fixed version won‚Äôt help

Author: Andy#1801
Content: But trusting code hosted on npm is a bad idea anyway. Because nobody reviews the minified code there... people just look at the git repo, but those codes dont have to match

Author: Andy#1801
Content: I keep coming to the conclusion that the ONLY way to be TRULY safe, is if you copy paste the source code of every singe dependency and sub dependency into your app by hand and review it. Which is just impossible if you don‚Äôt have a whole team of developers dedicated to doing that...

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: yes it is scary

Author: Andy#1801
Content: The problem is that many js repos need to be ‚Äúbuilt‚Äù somehow

Author: Andy#1801
Content: Typescript, babbel, etc

Author: Andy#1801
Content: But if npm built all the dependencies themselves that would already be a massive improvement

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
dukeleto#7326
Content: very often, you inherit thousands of nodeJS dependencies

Author: ComputerGenie üë¥üèºüì¢#7004
Content: yeah, that what I mean that you cannot stop while still using them

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: just from the start, I had a 10,000 line package-lock.json for Hush-NG code I inherited

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: most people are in that kind of situation

Author: Andy#1801
Content: As mentioned before, the problem is often that js lacks a lot of basic/useful features, so instead of programming it over and over again, you just include a package that does that specific task well. And then you end up with 1000s of small dependencies that is impossible to review.

Author: Andy#1801
Content: I would actually prefer if there is a huge single library with 0 dependencies that has all the code in one place. So instead of having 1000 small libraries of which the changes are almost impossible to track, you would have 1 huge library with 1000 smaller files. And then you pretty much just have to review that one. Still a pain in the ***, but I would personally prefer that.
